West Virginia Color-Coded Metrics

The governor and WVDHHR have created a color-coded metric to notify the public of the Covid-19 infection rate in each county. Mercer County Schools will change school schedules based on the infection rate at the time. The WV DHHR will update their Covid website each Saturday with current infection rates (https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/default.aspx), and that will determine the following week’s schedule. If Mercer County’s infection rate is red, schools will switch to remote immediately.

Elementary: Green = Blended Model A
Yellow = Blended Model A
Orange = Blended Model B
Red = Remote

Secondary: Green = Blended Model A
Yellow = Blended Model B
Orange = Blended Model B
Red = Remote

Blended Model A: 5 days a week
Blended Model B: Approximately 50% of students report to school every other day.

**For the full Reopening Plan details, visit https://boe.merc.k12.wv.us/domain/3128

Back to School?

As school systems across the nation wrestle with the question of how best to meet the educational needs of their students in the midst of a pandemic, Mercer County is no exception.

What will the school day look like? What restrictions will be necessary to facilitate having students in classrooms? Questions that were inconceivable to West Virginians prior to March 16, 2020 are now at the top of the priority list.

As we look toward the new school year we would like to have your input on the options that MAY exist for your child. While all plans are subject to the approval of the WVDHHR, the WVDE and ultimately the governor, it is essential that we continue to craft a reopening plan that not only meets the needs of our students but their families as well.

We would appreciate your taking a few minutes to complete a survey that includes potential school reopening models for Mercer County Schools this August.

The anonymous survey may be found by clicking on this link:

https://boe.merc.k12.wv.us/parents

Thank you,

Dr. Deborah S. Akers, Superintendent

As a result, Mercer County Schools will continue to follow the guidelines from the CDC on flu or flu-like illnesses. If a student becomes ill, we will take the student to an isolated area separated from the other children and contact the parents and or guardians. Additionally, we will continue to work with children to encourage frequent hand washing.

Finally, we encourage all parents/guardians to keep their child/children at home if they exhibit flu-like symptoms.

Athens Students Receive Awards for State Fire Safety
Poster Contest

PRINCETON, WV, November 4, 2019: For the fourth time, students from Athens Elementary School received honors for their Fire Safety Posters. In a surprise ceremony today at Athens School, West Virginia Fire Marshall Kenneth E. Tyree informed Samuel Butler, a Kindergarten student and Ethan Price, a fourth grade student, that they were among the twelve (12) finalists in the state. Their posters were chosen from student participants in over fifteen (15) West Virginia counties. Samuel is the son of Nick and Rachel Butler. Ethan is the son of Lee and Wendy Price.

Shelley Weiss, principal of Athens School, told the students how proud everyone was of her students’ work and accomplishments.
